title: 103_hr475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Patient Protection Act of 1993" and includes restrictions on carriers. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Patient Protection Act of 1993 limits the number of regional carriers to process claims for covered items and prohibits carrier forum shopping. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Patient Protection Act of 1993 limits regional carriers for processing claims and prohibits carrier forum shopping. The term "appropriate carrier" refers to the carrier with jurisdiction over the patient's residence area, with exceptions for patients living near a second carrier's jurisdiction or temporarily residing in a different geographic area. The term "appropriate carrier" refers to the carrier with jurisdiction over the patient's residence area, with exceptions for patients living near a second carrier's jurisdiction or temporarily residing in a different geographic area. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall apply with respect to contracts with carriers for items furnished on or after January 1, 1994. SEC. 3. Treatment of certain items as covered items; using reasonable cost as basis for determining payment amounts. The amendment to the Social Security Act includes adding ostomy supplies, tracheostomy supplies, urologicals, surgical dressings, splints, casts, and devices for fractures and dislocations as covered items. Additionally, these items are now considered inexpensive and routinely purchased. The Social Security Act amendment now includes ostomy supplies, tracheostomy supplies, urologicals, surgical dressings, splints, casts, and devices for fractures and dislocations as covered items. Amendments were made to sections 1834 and 1861 of the Act to reflect these changes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on basing payment amounts for durable medical equipment on reasonable costs, with a report due to Congress by January 1, 1995. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish guidelines for determining medical effectiveness and permitting payment for upgraded items under the Medicare program by January 1, 1995. A supplier may provide a patient with an item that is more expensive or exceeds the standard version eligible for payment under the Medicare program. SEC. 4. Certification and disclosure requirements for suppliers of durable medical equipment. The text chunk discusses the mandatory certification of suppliers of durable medical equipment under the Social Security Act. Payment for covered items furnished by suppliers is contingent upon the Secretary certifying that the supplier meets established certification standards. The Secretary will establish certification standards for suppliers of durable medical equipment, including criteria for suppliers and requirements for information disclosure. This includes details on how items are sourced and the identification of subcontracting entities involved in providing covered items to beneficiaries. The Secretary will establish certification standards for suppliers of durable medical equipment, including criteria for suppliers, requirements for information disclosure, a description of items and services provided, a list of states and counties served, and any additional information deemed appropriate. Fees for certification are also authorized. The Secretary may require a supplier to pay an administrative fee for certification or renewal, not exceeding $100. Fees collected will go to the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for administration. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify certification standards or fees for certain suppliers. The Secretary may impose an administrative fee on suppliers for certification, capped at $100, with fees going to the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Secretary can also waive or adjust certification standards or fees for specific suppliers. Additionally, a prohibition is in place against issuing multiple provider numbers to suppliers. The prohibition against issuing multiple provider numbers to suppliers is in place, except in cases where significant differences among items or geographic regions justify it. Additionally, limitations on employment relationships for exemption from anti-kickback requirements have been amended. The amendments made by this section, regarding employment relationships between nursing facility employees and suppliers of covered items, shall apply to items or services furnished on or after January 1, 1994. SEC. 5. PRIOR APPROVAL AUTHORIZED FOR ITEMS FURNISHED BY SUPPLIERS ENGAGED IN FRAUD OR ABUSIVE PRACTICES. The Secretary shall develop a list of suppliers engaged in fraudulent activities subject to penalties under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The Secretary will develop a list of suppliers involved in fraudulent activities subject to penalties under specific sections of the Social Security Act. Carriers must determine in advance if payment for items from listed suppliers may be denied under section 1862(a)(1). Additionally, a conforming amendment expands the sections under which penalties apply. The amendments made by this section apply to items and services furnished on or after January 1, 1994. SEC. 6. STUDY OF IMPACT OF REFORMS ON ACCESS TO AND COSTS OF DURABLE MEDICAL EQUIPMENT FOR MEDICARE BENEFICIARIES. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of amendments on Medicare part B enrollees' access to durable medical equipment and costs. The study will include an analysis of rural area residents. A report must be submitted to Congress by January 1, 1995. The General will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for legislative or regulatory changes to improve Medicare beneficiaries' access to durable medical equipment and control costs. This includes suggestions for imposing maximum allowable limits on charges to beneficiaries, similar to limits on physician services. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on durable medical equipment provided to individuals in nursing facilities under Medicare Part B, including an analysis of the need for additional controls. A report will be submitted to Congress by January 1, 1995.
